projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE ONE FROM THE LORD DIGBY TO THE QÆ²EENE: THE OTHER OF A LATE OVERTHROVV WHICH THE ENGLISH GAVE THE REBELLS IN IRELAND.

div.head: A TRVE COPIE OF THE LORD DIGBIES LETTER TO THE QÆ²EENE.
div.p:
I Shall not adventure to write unto your MajeÅ¿tie with freedome, but by expreÅ¿Å¿es, or till Å¿uch time as I have a Cypher, which I beÅ¿eech your MajeÅ¿tie to vouchÅ¿afe mee. At this time therefore I Å¿hall onely let your MajeÅ¿tie know where the humbleÅ¿t and moÅ¿t faithfull Å¿ervant you have in the world is, here at Middleborough, where I Å¿hall remaine in the privateÅ¿t way I can, till I receive inÅ¿tructions how I Å¿hall Å¿erve the King and your MajeÅ¿tie in theÅ¿e parts. If the King betake himÅ¿elfe to a Å¿afe place, where he may avow and protect his Å¿ervants from rage and violence, for from
IuÅ¿tice I will never implore it. I Å¿hall then live in impatience and in miÅ¿ery till I waite upon you. But if after all he hath done of late, he Å¿hall betake himÅ¿elfe to the eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t and complianteÅ¿t wayes of accommodation, I am confident, that then I Å¿hall Å¿erve him more by my abÅ¿ence, than by all my induÅ¿try: and it will be a comfort to mee in all calamities, if I cannot Å¿erve you by my actions, that I may doe it in Å¿ome kinde by my Å¿ufferings for your Å¿ake, having (I proteÅ¿t to God) no meaÅ¿ure of happineÅ¿Å¿e or misfortune in this world, but what I derive from your MaieÅ¿ties value of my affection and fidelitie.

div.head: Ioyfull News from Jreland, or a true relation of the great overthrow which the EngliÅ¿h gave the Rebels before Droheda, &c.
div.p:
IN my laÅ¿t to you, I Å¿ignified to you, the difficulties which were like to befall us by the releeving of Droheda, but God by his infinite mercy hath freed us (I may Å¿ay miraculouÅ¿ly) from that hazard: for when our men there were driven to that extremitie to eat horÅ¿e-fleÅ¿h, Sir Henry Tichbourne Å¿allied out of the Town with onely fortie Musketiers, and fortie HorÅ¿e, and beat off foure hundred of the Enemies, killed above threeÅ¿core of them, recovered fourÅ¿core Cowes and Oxen, and two hundred Å¿heep; burned foure Towns, and brought home two of their Colours. BeÅ¿ides, I muÅ¿t relate unto you Gods abundant goodneÅ¿Å¿e unto us, in that the night before the releefe and Å¿uccours which we Å¿ent by Sea from Dublin to them, Å¿hould have entred into the Harbour
of Droheda, (which was Å¿trongly fenced over with a Chain and Å¿everall boates) there happened a Å¿torme which broke their chaines, and gave our men Å¿o free a paÅ¿Å¿age, as with little difficultie they came Å¿afely to the Town. The Rebels were gathered at KilÅ¿halgham within Å¿even miles of Dublin, above two thouÅ¿and men, where they were Å¿etled in a verie Å¿trongwood. My Lord of Ormond carried out part of our Armie, and beat them out of that great Å¿trength (for they would not come into the Champaine) and killed above a hundred of them, without any conÅ¿iderable loÅ¿Å¿e of our Å¿ide, onely Captain James Rochfort, a moÅ¿t gallant and couragious Gentleman. This was an act of great braverie, wherein Sir Charles Coote did, (as he doth alwayes) beyond expectation, expoÅ¿ing his perÅ¿on to as much danger as any man living could; and in truth he is a gallant man, full of courage and good affections, and deÅ¿erves great incouragement from that Å¿ide. Our Souldiers are in great want of money, which cauÅ¿es a generall want of all other neceÅ¿Å¿aries, yet notwithÅ¿tanding God hath infuÅ¿ed Å¿uch courage into them (for undoubtedly it is his work) that they think there is no danger Å¿o great, but they may attempt it.

Colonell Munke is arrived here with my Lord Lieutenants Regiment of fifteen hundred foot, and Sir Richard Grevill with neer foure hundred HorÅ¿e, which puts much heart into us, and makes us look big upon our neighbours, yet we grieve we cannot be able to releeve our friends in other parts; but I hope when our full Å¿uccours Å¿hall come, we Å¿hall not onely defend this place, but adde comfort to our poore diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed friends abroad.
The enemy though their numbers be verie great, even beyond beleef, yet their hearts begin to faint, and I beleeve they repent their furious madneÅ¿Å¿e.

If my Brother be in London, I pray you impart this Letter to him, I would have written to him, but that I thought he was at CheÅ¿ter, or in his way thither; By the next he Å¿hall hear from me at large, and I Å¿hall likewiÅ¿e trouble you.
I muÅ¿t now onely tell you, that I thank you for your care of thoÅ¿e things which concern me, and that I am, Sir, your moÅ¿t affectionate Å¿ervant,

closer.signed: Tis this day ordered forthwith that this Letter be publiÅ¿hed in Print. H. ElÅ¿ing. Cler. P. D. Com.
